Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: King of the hill? How competitive interactions affect biogeographical pattern and species responses to environmental variability.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants are moving up mountainsides into cooler climates as temperatures have increased. An understudied consequence of this movement is that alpine species, which cannot move further up mountains, may become rarer because of more competition with the upward migrating species. Could this intensified competition be strong enough to cause species extinctions? This research will provide one of the few experimental tests of this scenario, using alpine plant communities of the southern Rocky Mountains, CO, USA. This project expands upon past work by coupling competition experiments with mathematical models to predict population growth into the future and to generalize the results to other ecosystems. This research will provide new insights for the management of alpine and other ecosystems under variable temperature and precipitation patterns, specifically for species important in wildlife management, recreation, and restoration. In addition, this project will provide research opportunities for undergraduate students and the public by utilizing the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory's Science Festival and Kids Nature Camp outreach programs.

The researchers have used niche models to inform an experiment that transplanted alpine species into the low elevation plant communities expected to encroach upslope. Results suggest that focal alpine species performance is reduced more by low elevation plant communities than by resident alpine communities. The researchers are combining demographic data from natural populations with field manipulations of competition to parameterize integral projection models. These models are aimed at long-term predictions of focal species population growth under experimental conditions to determine their viability in a competitive environment altered by increased temperatures. This project will generalize these results to a wider set of systems and species. The researchers will collect plant trait and environmental data on focal species and competing communities to parameterize a new trait-based model aimed at predicting competitive interaction outcomes from differences in species traits. By predicating the competitive environment on newly measured trait-environment relationships, this project will produce a priori predictions of plant performance in various physical and competitive environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under warming climates, plant species are moving up mountain slopes as environmental conditions become more favorable for their growth. These migrating plant species may use more sunlight, water, and nutrients than less resource-acquisitive alpine species, and competitively dominate the communities they colonize. Additionally, mammalian herbivores such as deer and moose are expected to forage higher on mountains under warmer climates, but how will increased consumption by herbivores affect alpine plant species? Our studies rigorously tested these predictions for alpine plant communities in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado. First, we created models to predict where on the landscape competition among plants and consumption by animals will be important in determining how plants respond to climate change and novel interactions with competitors and herbivores. Second, we performed experiments that tested whether upward migrating competitors/herbivores can drive population declines in alpine plants. Low elevation competitors did not reduce alpine species’ population growth to a great extent, but increased herbivory has potential to cause population declines under warming-driven shifts in mammal foraging. Third, we constructed a model that uses plant traits for resource acquisition to predict how alpine plants will compete with upwardly migrating plant species that reduce plant growth more than current alpine residents. Taller and thin-leaved competitors were more common in low elevation communities and caused greater reductions in focal species fitness compared to their short and thick-leaved competitors in alpine environments. Altogether, our work suggests that a combination of increased herbivory and novel competitors may drive individual fitness and population declines of alpine plant species beyond the direct effects of climate change. 

 

We have published three scientific journal articles as a result of this award and have five manuscripts in preparation. We leveraged this award to advise nine undergraduate researchers on independent projects, which led to two scientific journal publications, two honors theses, and five summer REU projects. The award has led to data products made freely available for other researchers, such as climate interpolations for the Colorado Rocky Mountain Upper Gunnison Basin region. Finally, PI Lynn developed a game for kids (K-2) that demonstrates the principals of plant-plant competition and disseminated his research to stakeholders of the region with a seminar in RMBL’s Science Sampler. He began a 3-year postdoctoral fellowship at the University of Bergen in July 2019.
